pullRequest.body:
This adds a file `Mathlib.NumberTheory.LSeries.Deriv` that contains results on differentiability and derivatives of L-series, including the fact that the L-series is holomorphic on its right half-plane of absolute convergence.

See [this thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/L-series/near/424858837) on Zulip.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
> I feel that the arguments here could be shortened substantially by using `Complex.hasSum_deriv_of_summable_norm` in place of `hasFDerivAt_tsum`. The point is that for a series `âˆ‘' n, f n x`, the latter result requires a locally-uniform summable bound on `deriv f`, but the former only requires a locally-uniform summable bound on `f` (which is automatic under your assumptions).

I've changed it. It is not that much shorter, though (we need to combine [Complex.differentiableOn_tsum_of_summable_norm](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Complex/LocallyUniformLimit.html#Complex.differentiableOn_tsum_of_summable_norm) and [Complex.hasSum_deriv_of_summable_norm](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Complex/LocallyUniformLimit.html#Complex.hasSum_deriv_of_summable_norm), and we still need to use a closed  half-plane contained in the open half-plane and containing `s`).

One could perhaps use this to deduce summability results on `log * f` from this (thus saving a few lines earlier in the file), but I think it is worth having the explicit estimate in `LSeries.norm_term_logMul_le_of_re_lt_re` in any case.

> 
> One could perhaps use this to deduce summability results on `log * f` from this (thus saving a few lines earlier in the file), but I think it is worth having the explicit estimate in `LSeries.norm_term_logMul_le_of_re_lt_re` in any case.

Actually that was kind of the point of my message: that using these more powerful analytic results saves us the trouble of having to prove `log * f` is summable, and thus removes the need for these explicit bounds. (What else do you envisage this estimate being useful for?)
OK, I'm done golfing. I've commented out some lemmas â€“ these are ones where I'm sceptical about whether they're useful; if you feel strongly then feel free to reinstate them.

I have now moved `Complex.isOpen_rightHalfPlane` from `Deriv.lean` to `Convergence.lean` (which is the file talking about abscissae of convergence, so it should fit better there, even though it is not actually needed in that file) and edited the comment preceding it.
If there are no further points that need discussion, I think this should be ready to go now.

LGTM

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by loefflerd.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

I feel that the arguments here could be shortened substantially by using ~~`Complex.differentiableOn_tsum_of_summable_norm`~~ (edit: I meant `Complex.hasSum_deriv_of_summable_norm`, sorry) in place of `hasFDerivAt_tsum`. The point is that for a series `âˆ‘' n, f n x`, the latter result requires a locally-uniform summable bound on `deriv f`, but the former only requires a locally-uniform summable bound on `f` (which is automatic under your assumptions). 

(The downside of `Complex.differentiableOn_tsum_of_summable_norm` is that it only works for 1-variable functions, but this covers the intended applications here.)

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

```suggestion
  there is the negative of the `LSeries` of the point-wise product `log * f` (`LSeries.deriv`).
```
Fixed, thanks!

Here's a suggestion. One could add the lemma
````
lemma EReal.isOpen_gt (x : EReal) {Î± : Type*} [TopologicalSpace Î±] {f : Î± â†’ â„} (hf : Continuous f) :
    IsOpen {a : Î± | x < f a} :=
  isOpen_lt continuous_const <| EReal.continuous_coe_iff.mpr hf
````
to `Mathlib.Topology.Instances.EReal` (and its obvious mirror-image). Then the uses of `isOpen_rightHalfPlane` can be replaced with things like `(EReal.isOpen_gt _ continuous_re)` (at line 199 and 229) or the dot-notation `... <| (abscissaOfAbsConv f).isOpen_gt continuous_re` (for the last line). Just a suggestion, feel free to ignore if you prefer another approach.
I think it is nice to have this version available, so I'd like to keep it. But perhaps the name should be changed to `EReal.isOpen_complexRightHalfPlane`? This would allow for dot notation.

IMHO, dot-notation is a nice thing to have, but we shouldn't let it override the use of namespaces to keep related results together â€“Â a lemma which is specifically about complex numbers should not go in the `EReal` namespace.
OK. I'll leave it as is.

Would you be happy with renaming `Complex.isOpen_rightHalfPlane` to `Complex.isOpen_re_gt_EReal` and moving it (and its three obvious variants) to either a new file, or one of the existing files, in the `Analysis/Complex` directory?
That's perfectly OK for me. It will have to be a new file though; I don't think it makes sense to add an import of `EReal` stuff to one of the existing files under `Analysis/Conmplex`.
Do you actually use this? It seems it is not used in `LSeries.iteratedDeriv`, so I suggest deleting it, it's not particularly interesting in itself.
OK.

I suggest using the built-in API for iterating operations, `logMul^[n] f` (which is syntatic sugar for `Nat.iterate logMul n f`); this has its own lemmas `Function.iterate_zero`, `Function.iterate_succ` etc, so you don't need to roll your own.
OK.

How useful is this, really? I'm a bit sceptical of the value of statements of the form `deriv f = foo`, since virtually any non-trivial place where you use them will need a differentiability hypothesis anyway, and if you prove that, you've just proved the two separate parts of `HasDerivAt f foo`.
The first is used in the proof of `LSeries.LSeriesSummable_logMul_and_hasDerivAt`: one needs to know the derivatives of the terms in the sum. One could replace it by its proof there, I assume.
I suggest swapping the numbers for readability
Feel free to do that.

I usually go for `exists_between` for this sort of thing rather than taking the explicit midpoint. I had a reviewer patch in the works which golfed this proof considerably (reducing h3 and h4 to one line each) but it conflicts with your latest commit, I'll try rebasing it.
OK.

Shouldn't this lemma also be in the namespace `LSeries`, as `abscissaOfAbsConv` is already in this namespace? In fact, I wonder if all the file shouldn't be in this namespace -- for instance, the previous lemma `LSeriesSummable.logMul_of_lt_re` is not in it, but I'm not sure it buys anything as it's not well suited to dot notation.
I don't think anything here is dot-notatable, sinceÂ `LSeries` is not Type-valued; but there might be an argument for putting stuff in the `LSeries` namespace anyway just for organisational purposes.
Yes, I just meant for organisational purposes and to avoid cluttering the root namespace.
I'll have a look and try to come up with something consistent. (Right now, I am travelling, so this will have to wait a couple of days.)

I do think it makes sense to put the results on the abscissa of convergence into the `LSeries` namespace (as argued by SÃ©bastien). On the other hand, by analogy with `Summable`/`HasSum`/`tsum`, I think most of the other results should have names like `LSeries_<blah>`.
I have adapted the names accordingly; I hope this is OK with everyone.
The current naming scheme looks fine to me

The usual practice for `congr` lemmas is, I think, to have a one-way implication set up for dot-notation:
````
lemma LSeriesSummable.congr' {f g : â„• â†’ â„‚} {s : â„‚} (hf : LSeriesSummable f s) (hfg : f =á¶ [atTop] g) : LSeriesSummable g s := sorry
````
and then the `iff` version outside the namespace. Since you are already proving the one-way implication inside your proof anyway, this just amounts to giving it a name.
OK, done.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/LSeries/Deriv): derivatives of L-series
